description: The Philippines Bacolod City also ordered the implementation of a curfew here from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. (announced and effective on Mar. 17)

The Philippines Bacolod City Mayor Evelio Leonardia, in a late afternoon news conference at the Government Center here, announced that he had signed Executive Order No. 26 that places the city under an Enhanced Community Quarantine from 30 March to 14 April 2020. A 24-hour curfew will be observed by the general public, except for identified holders of Home Quarantine Pass who will be allowed to leave for provisions from 4 am to 10 pm.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description:
The Philippine Foreign Service Posts are temporarily suspending the issuance of visas, effective immediately, to the following:

1) Foreign nationals directly coming from China and its Special Administrative Regions; and
2) Foreign nationals, who, within fourteen (14) days immediately preceding arrival in the Philippines, have been to China, and its Special Administrative Regions.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs: (announced and effective on March 3)

- Temporary travel restriction for all Filipinos traveling into North Gyeongsang Province (including Daegu City and Cheongdo County) of South Korea.

- All Filipinos going to South Korea (with the exception of North Gyeongsang Province including Daegu City and Cheongdo County) are allowed to proceed with their journey provided that they shall execute and sign a declaration signifying their knowledge and understanding of the risks involved in proceeding with their trip. All travelers shall likewise be handed out a health advisory pamphlet upon departure.

- Overseas Filipino Workers (OFWs), students studying in South Korea, and those with Permanent Resident status are not restricted to travel into South Korea.

- OFWs (whether returning or newly-hired) as well as dependents of permanent residents are allowed to return to South Korea but they must also execute a Declaration signifying their knowledge and understanding of the risks involved upon their return to the country.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
target_province: North Gyeongsang Province (including Daegu City and Cheongdo County)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs: (announced and effective on March 3)

- Temporary ban of entry into the Philippines of any person coming from the North Gyeongsang Province (including Daegu City and Cheongdo County) of South Korea.

- Temporary ban of entry into the Philippines of any person who has been to the North Gyeongsang Province (including Daegu City and Cheongdo County) of South Korea within 14 days immediately preceding their arrival in the Philippines.

Filipino citizens, including their foreign spouses and children, holders of Permanent Resident Visas, and holders of Diplomatic Visas issued by the Philippine Government are exempted from this temporary travel ban but must follow the health protocols of the Department of Health.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
target_province: North Gyeongsang Province (including Daegu City and Cheongdo County)

description:
Foreign nationals are temporarily barred anew from entering the country after the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) suspended its issuance of visas in all foreign service posts all over the world. (announced on Mar. 20 and effective on Mar. 22)

Only OFWs (overseas Filipino workers), repatriating Filipinos, their foreign spouses and children (provided that the foreign spouse and children are traveling with the Filipino national), foreign government and international organization officials accredited to the Philippines, will be allowed to enter the country.

description:
The Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has signed a law on March 25 that grants him special powers to step up the government’s fight against the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19).

In a text message sent to reporters early Wednesday morning, Senator Christopher Lawrence Go confirmed that Duterte inked Republic Act (RA) 11469 or the "Bayanihan to Heal as One Act".
type_text: The Congress grants the President of the Philippines special powers to tackle COVID-19.
